trans-unit.source: Microsoft Identity Brokers
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Identity Brokers

trans-unit.source: Microsoft provides applications for every mobile platform that allow for the bridging of credentials across applications from different vendors as well as allows for special enhanced features that require a single secure place from where to validate credentials.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft provides applications for every mobile platform that allow for the bridging of credentials across applications from different vendors as well as allows for special enhanced features that require a single secure place from where to validate credentials.

trans-unit.source: We call these **brokers**.
trans-unit.target: We call these **brokers**.

trans-unit.source: On iOS and Android these are provided through downloadable applications that customers either install independently or can be pushed to the device by a company who manages some or all of the device for their employee.
trans-unit.target: On iOS and Android these are provided through downloadable applications that customers either install independently or can be pushed to the device by a company who manages some or all of the device for their employee.

trans-unit.source: These brokers support managing security just for some applications or the entire device based on what IT Administrators desire.
trans-unit.target: These brokers support managing security just for some applications or the entire device based on what IT Administrators desire.

trans-unit.source: In Windows this functionality is provided by an account chooser built in to the operating system, known technically as the Web Authentication Broker.
trans-unit.target: In Windows this functionality is provided by an account chooser built in to the operating system, known technically as the Web Authentication Broker.

trans-unit.source: To understand how we use these brokers and how your customers might see them in their login flow for the Microsoft Identity platform read on for more information.
trans-unit.target: To understand how we use these brokers and how your customers might see them in their login flow for the Microsoft Identity platform read on for more information.

trans-unit.source: Access to credentials on devices follow two basic patterns for the Microsoft Identity platform:
trans-unit.target: Access to credentials on devices follow two basic patterns for the Microsoft Identity platform:

trans-unit.source: Non-broker assisted logins
trans-unit.target: Non-broker assisted logins

trans-unit.source: Broker assisted logins
trans-unit.target: Broker assisted logins

trans-unit.source: Non-broker assisted logins
trans-unit.target: Non-broker assisted logins

trans-unit.source: Non-broker assisted logins are login experiences that happen inline with the application and use the local storage on the device for that application.
trans-unit.target: Non-broker assisted logins are login experiences that happen inline with the application and use the local storage on the device for that application.

trans-unit.source: This storage may be shared across applications but the credentials are tightly bound to the app or suite of apps using that credential.
trans-unit.target: This storage may be shared across applications but the credentials are tightly bound to the app or suite of apps using that credential.

trans-unit.source: This is the experience you've most likely experienced in many mobile applications where you enter a username and password within the application itself.
trans-unit.target: This is the experience you've most likely experienced in many mobile applications where you enter a username and password within the application itself.

trans-unit.source: These logins have the following benefits:
trans-unit.target: These logins have the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: User experience exists entirely within the application.
trans-unit.target: User experience exists entirely within the application.

trans-unit.source: Credentials can be shared across applications that are signed by the same certificate, providing a single sign-on experience to your suite of applications.
trans-unit.target: Credentials can be shared across applications that are signed by the same certificate, providing a single sign-on experience to your suite of applications.

trans-unit.source: Control around the experience of logging in is provided to the application before and after sign-in.
trans-unit.target: Control around the experience of logging in is provided to the application before and after sign-in.

trans-unit.source: These logins have the following drawbacks:
trans-unit.target: These logins have the following drawbacks:

trans-unit.source: User cannot experience single-sign on across all apps that use a Microsoft Identity, only across those Microsoft Identities that are your application owns and have configured.
trans-unit.target: User cannot experience single-sign on across all apps that use a Microsoft Identity, only across those Microsoft Identities that are your application owns and have configured.

trans-unit.source: Your application can not be used with more advanced business features such as Conditional Access or use the InTune suite of products.
trans-unit.target: Your application can not be used with more advanced business features such as Conditional Access or use the InTune suite of products.

trans-unit.source: Your application can't support certificate based authentication for business users.
trans-unit.target: Your application can't support certificate based authentication for business users.

trans-unit.source: Broker assisted logins
trans-unit.target: Broker assisted logins

trans-unit.source: Broker-assisted logins are login experiences that occur within the broker application and use the storage and security of the broker to share credentials across all applications on the device that leverage the Microsoft Identity platform.
trans-unit.target: Broker-assisted logins are login experiences that occur within the broker application and use the storage and security of the broker to share credentials across all applications on the device that leverage the Microsoft Identity platform.

trans-unit.source: This means that your applications will rely on the broker in order to sign users in.
trans-unit.target: This means that your applications will rely on the broker in order to sign users in.

trans-unit.source: On iOS and Android these are provided through downloadable applications that customers either install independently or can be pushed to the device by a company who manages the device for their user.
trans-unit.target: On iOS and Android these are provided through downloadable applications that customers either install independently or can be pushed to the device by a company who manages the device for their user.

trans-unit.source: An example of this type of application is the Azure Authenticator application on iOS.
trans-unit.target: An example of this type of application is the Azure Authenticator application on iOS.

trans-unit.source: In Windows this functionality is provided by an account chooser built in to the operating system, known technically as the Web Authentication Broker.
trans-unit.target: In Windows this functionality is provided by an account chooser built in to the operating system, known technically as the Web Authentication Broker.

trans-unit.source: The experience varies by platform and can sometimes be disruptive to users if not managed correctly.
trans-unit.target: The experience varies by platform and can sometimes be disruptive to users if not managed correctly.

trans-unit.source: You're probably most familiar with this pattern if you have the Facebook application installed and use Facebook Login functionality in another application.
trans-unit.target: You're probably most familiar with this pattern if you have the Facebook application installed and use Facebook Login functionality in another application.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Identity platform leverages the same pattern.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Identity platform leverages the same pattern.

trans-unit.source: For iOS this leads to a "transition" animation where your application is sent to the background while the Azure Authenticator applications comes to the foreground for the user to select which account they would like to sign in with.
trans-unit.target: For iOS this leads to a "transition" animation where your application is sent to the background while the Azure Authenticator applications comes to the foreground for the user to select which account they would like to sign in with.

trans-unit.target: For Android and Windows the account chooser is displayed on top of your application which is less disruptive to the user.

trans-unit.source: How the broker gets invoked
trans-unit.target: How the broker gets invoked

trans-unit.source: If a compatible broker is installed on the device, like the Azure Authenticator application, the Microsoft Identity SDKs will automatically do the work of invoking the broker for you when a user indicates they wish to log in using any account from the Microsoft Identity platform.
trans-unit.target: If a compatible broker is installed on the device, like the Azure Authenticator application, the Microsoft Identity SDKs will automatically do the work of invoking the broker for you when a user indicates they wish to log in using any account from the Microsoft Identity platform.

trans-unit.source: This could be a personal Microsoft Account, a work or school account, or an account that you provide and host in Azure using our B2C and B2B products.
trans-unit.target: This could be a personal Microsoft Account, a work or school account, or an account that you provide and host in Azure using our B2C and B2B products.

trans-unit.source: By using extremely secure algorithms and encryption we ensure that the credentials are asked for and delivered back to your application in a secure manner.
trans-unit.target: By using extremely secure algorithms and encryption we ensure that the credentials are asked for and delivered back to your application in a secure manner.

trans-unit.source: The exact technical detail of these mechanisms is not published but have been developed with collaboration by Apple and Google.
trans-unit.target: The exact technical detail of these mechanisms is not published but have been developed with collaboration by Apple and Google.

trans-unit.source: The developer has the choice of if the Microsoft Identity SDK calls the broker or uses the non-broker assisted flow.
trans-unit.target: The developer has the choice of if the Microsoft Identity SDK calls the broker or uses the non-broker assisted flow.

trans-unit.source: However if the developer chooses not to use the broker-assisted flow they lose the benefit of leveraging SSO credentials that the user may have already added on the device as well as prevents their application from being used with business features Microsoft provides its customers such as Conditional Access, Intune Management capabilities, and certificate based authentication.
trans-unit.target: However if the developer chooses not to use the broker-assisted flow they lose the benefit of leveraging SSO credentials that the user may have already added on the device as well as prevents their application from being used with business features Microsoft provides its customers such as Conditional Access, Intune Management capabilities, and certificate based authentication.
